text: Hello people!! This is Sargi, (pronouns: she/her) logging in from Bangalore, India. I write content and copy. I sell my services through <http://contentcreatorsargi.com/>. My last full-time job was developing content for students in 2013. But I've been writing blogs, website content, and landing page copy since 2010. Love the idea of meeting up with people who're all in the content business.

text:
Hi everyone,

I'm Katja, I now live in the Eastern part of Germany, halfway between Hamburg and Berlin (actually, I'm in the middle of moving here). I work part-time as digital and content strategist in an international PR agency/comms consultancy, and spend the remaining time trying to build my own business doing trainings and workshops on digital comms and platforms.

I started my first blog in 2005 and focussed on digital and social media content and strategies ever since I started working full-time in 2007. I also have a strong monitoring/analytics background, which is why it is still a little difficult to position myself as a content person within our agency.

I'm really excited to have found this platform of like-minded content people and I'm looking forward to learning from and with all of you. :)

text:
Hi Garrett! Super intrigued by you recent business shift.

What's surprised you the most about the micro-agency model?

elements.text:
Hi Garrett! Super intrigued by you recent business shift.

What's surprised you the most about the micro-agency model?

text:
Hey <@UL4TUV38B>! What has surprised me is how good it feels to see writing tasks on my project task list and know I don't have to do them =D

It has also surprised me how much it's made me feel like a legit business, rather than a legit freelancer - hard to describe that one.

Now I'm trying to find the balance between (1) estimating time involved to execute bigger agency projects, which tend to be multi-month content plans, and (2) copywriting projects that are 100% mine to do. The estimation process I use for myself was easy, because it was super easy to know exactly how much time I had to offer. The estimation process for agency work is more complicated, because there are more people / steps involved. Still working this one out.

text:
I've gotten quite good at bad estimates, if that helps :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

<@U019UEW7AQ2> I have minimal experience with managing workloads beyond my own, so take this with a grain of salt, but what I have tried has worked pretty well across both scenarios you describe. In a nutshell, you need to treat your own time like an employee - add the same estimates to your tasks as your contractors, and then use a tool like <https://asana.com/product/workload|Asana Workload> or <https://toggl.com/plan/|Toggl Plan> to see everyone's workloads together. Side note: Asana is :fire:, but it's also $$$ for the Business plan.

I was only managing content workflows, but I added story points to each task:
• 2pts for research
• 3pts for outline
• 5pts for drafting
• 1pt for polish (adding backlinks, formatting, SEO, etc.)
• 1pt for revisions
• 1pt for copyediting
• 1pt for publishing / adding to CMS
• 1-2pts for editing someone else's article (depending on length)
It doesn't matter what point values you choose - just make sure they're all relative to each other. I picked by saying "OK, outlining an article takes less time than drafting, but more time than researching and finding quotes and examples." Scientific, I know.

The key was then picking the right WIP limit, which for me was 5pts per day. That kept me from trying to outline and draft one post in the same day, trying to draft two posts at once, etc. 25pts per week also gave me enough buffer that when work inevitably took longer than expected, I wasn't swamped with other work that also needed doing. 25pts felt like about a 60% workload, which inevitably blew out to 80% of my time, which felt about right. Both Asana and Toggl Plan will get angry at you if you try to exceed your WIP limit, helping to keep you in check (and improve your estimates over time).

The nice thing about the system is that it's adaptable. Pick different story points for conversion copywriting tasks, for example, or apply the same points values to your contractors' work. Over time, you'll learn that X points takes Y time given Z contractors, then your estimates will slowly become more accurate.

Hope this helps :+1:

elements.text: I've gotten quite good at bad estimates, if that helps

text:
Dude I would story point my kid's bedtime routine if they would let me :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

The reason it doesn't work for most teams is that they don't adhere to WIP limits, and they also try and equate points too closely with time. X points might mean Y hours for one team, and Z hours for another - therefore one team will always look less productive than the other based on points throughput. But as long as you're only doing it for forecasting WITHIN EACH TEAM, and not trying to compare points org-wide, it works a treat.

Interested to see how it translates into Clickup. They let you use custom fields for things like story points, if I'm remembering right?

text: I stopped doing the points estimation earlier this year, when the one client I was running the micro-agency model for dropped off. But it was super handy for giving me confidence to over-book my workload (i.e. more than 25pts per week) and sub out the extra work, and also for forecasting workloads 4-6 weeks out. I really should try it again :thinking_face:

text:
Hi y’all! :wave: I’m a content marketer at <http://hackerrank.com|HackerRank>, a technical assessment platform out of the Bay Area. Before HackerRank, I spent time as a freelancer, and in marketing communications at an SEO software company, Searchmetrics. Outside of work, you’ll usually find me playing video games or working on growing the agency I recently started with my two work friends. So excited to meet y’all & start sharing ideas!

Feel free to add me on LinkedIn <https://www.linkedin.com/in/danayfrederick|here> :slightly_smiling_face:
